data.text: The Best Brooks Saddle for an Upright Bicycle for Touring?
What's the best Brooks saddle for an upright bicycle for touring?
The B67
data.author: Tony Mitchelhill

data.text: A friend has recommended this.
data.author: Robert Zehr

data.text: I have a B67 on my Disk Trucker.. Is like an armchair after my 90s mountain bikes
data.author: Chris Joy

data.text: There's no one size fits all. Personal favorite is the C17.
data.author: Jake Klamerus

data.text: How upright? The more upright you sit, the wider the saddle you'll need. Brooks provides the measurements for width, length and height for every saddle. Depends on what you mean by "upright" - sit-up-and-beg vs typical touring position.
data.author: David Rowe

data.text: Not drop bars but more moustache type. Might be 75 degree.
data.author: Robert Zehr

data.text: Maybe also take a look at the SQ Lab page, as they have saddles designed for different amounts of "uprightness". I'm not sure if they have any information on their rationale, but worth taking a look.
data.author: David Rowe

data.text: The one you can try before you buy! Lol.
data.author: Angela M Freeman

data.text: Go get a saddle fit
data.author: Andy McMahon

data.text: Is there a good Brooks saddle at all is the real question. I don't think so.
data.author: Mitchell Paul

data.text: What seat do you recommend?
data.author: Robert Zehr

data.text: You need to try saddles and see which ones suit you. I love my Brooks B17 Imperial, it was comfy from the day I bought it, because I tried a few and found this one suited me best, and it's getting more and more comfortable as it breaks in.
data.author: Phil Metcalfe

data.text: I ride B 17 on all my bikes. Eventually your butt will break in and the saddle will feel good. I have had them for 10 years and they are still just as hard as rocks. Love them.
data.author: Bill Adkins

data.text: - same here, have 4 of them. Just bought a carved B17 to try, as one of my other B17s was damaged. All my B17s have been comfortable from day 1. Guess I’m just the right shape for them
data.author: Adrian Camm

data.text: Bj41
data.author: Doug Earle

data.text: What is that?
data.author: Robert Zehr

data.text: I LOVE the B67. Best saddle I've ever used.
data.author: Jared O'Moore-Klopf

data.text: Love my B17 titanium. My C17 is loathsome.
data.author: David Sykes

data.text: Whichever one you choose, make sure your sitbones are planted firmly on the back flare of the saddle to support your weight. For me I love my B17, but others like the springs in them like the Brooks Flyer. Depends on what kind of riding you're planning on doing. Regardless, if you're buying a leather saddle make sure to get a small tin of proofide and a rain cover. Good luck with your search!
data.author: David J. Syrotiak

data.text: Love my c17
data.author: Steven Orton

data.author: Topher Nando

data.text: I ride the B67.
data.author: David Campbell

data.text: B-17s are all I buy… for a dozen bikes… including my touring bike…
data.author: Howard Maher

data.text: B17 on my commuter. Selle Italia Flite on everything else!
data.author: Richard McCaughey

data.text: Brooks B67 maybe? I love mine.
data.author: Travis Steele

data.text: I ride a Surly LHT touring bike and I ride I a Brooks Flyer Imperial. The springs help to dampen the ride.
data.author: Mary Ann Latzgo Padglick

data.text: I have a flyer special. It’s basically a B67 with springs. It is the most comfortable saddle on any of my five bikes.
data.author: Ryan Cram

data.text: Comfort is most important aspect of long distance bicycle riding…..
data.author: David O'Neill

data.text: Not sure why your are limiting yourself to Brooks? IF its because you just love Brooks, or get a discount, ok. IF its because you want a leather saddle, there are other options out there. I spent the last 37 years looking for that perfect saddle, took me 20 years, but I finally found what works for me. On long rides, 70-205 I was having to use bum gels, but that always seemed wrong. Did a few different brooks saddles, & did actually break in a B17, though in truth it broke me in. I still have it. But my other 3 bikes have Sella Anatomica. Comfort from the start. No break in period. Once its set up correctly, I needed no bum gel. It is a very personal 1 of 3 connections to the bike & IF it does not work, then it does not work. That is my experience. All the best in your travels.
data.author: Pat Matson

data.text: I have heard the same about Sella Anatomica from one person, another complained they were too long. I guess it depends on what best fits you.
data.author: Robert Zehr

data.text: I would point out that, Brooks did copy Sella Antomica, with the slot &the longer rails. For me both are critical along with no break in time. But hey its personal, I would recommend trying different setups. All the best.
data.author: Pat Matson

data.text: An ergon ?
data.author: William Sloth

data.text: I use a C19 (didn't want to worry if my seat got wet).
data.author: Richard Neville
Paul Correia

data.text: I use a b17 imperial but I'm not completely upright
data.author: Jesse Justice

data.text: Try lots of saddles til you find the one that fits. It’s like finding your true love. You’ll have to kiss a lot of frogs.
data.author: Bettegail Shively

data.text: Upright is a bad idea. Brooks are only one of numerous options
data.author: Nigel Strang

data.text: I tour on a very upright Specialized Roll bike and I have a Brooks B67. I have no complaints.
data.author: Sean McMillan

data.text: The best one is the one that fits/suits you. Nobody else can tell that.
data.author: John Kane

data.text: Brooks "Conquest"
